question_text: Based on the thermoanalytical approach described in the paper, explain how the location of the reaction interface (inner vs. outer) for aluminum oxidation was determined and how this affects void formation and mechanical stress development in the oxide shell during heating. Include the specific experimental methodology used to identify the reaction interface location, focusing on the analysis of thermogravimetric data from powders with different particle size distributions.
standard_answer: The paper describes an experimental method using thermogravimetric (TG) measurements with aluminum powders having different but overlapping particle size distributions. By processing TG curves and comparing mass gains for particles of the same size from both powders under different oxidation scenarios, the location of the reaction interface was determined. The analysis showed that oxidation in oxygen occurs at the outer oxide-gas interface, with aluminum diffusing outward through the oxide shell. This mechanism leads to the formation of a void between the shrinking aluminum core and the rigid oxide shell. As a consequence of the oxidation on the outside of the particle and the rigidity of the oxide shell, there is competition between volume decrease of the core – increase in void volume – due to consumption, and core volume increase – decrease in void volume – due to thermal expansion and melting. The presence or absence of this void determines the mechanical stress on the oxide shell. When a void exists, it mitigates tensile stresses from thermal expansion and melting. If case (c) most accurately describes the oxidation mechanism, hollow oxide shells containing partially consumed aluminum should result from the reaction. This was confirmed by SEM images of undisturbed samples showing spherical particles with intact oxide shells, validating the outer interface reaction mechanism and associated void formation.

question_text: How does the location of the reaction interface differ between aluminum oxidation in dry oxygen versus steam environments, and what implications does this have for oxidation completion temperatures?
standard_answer: The location of the reaction interface differs fundamentally between dry oxygen and steam environments due to distinct diffusion mechanisms and oxide layer properties. In dry oxygen, oxidation occurs at the outer oxide-gas interface, where aluminum diffuses outward through the growing alumina layer. This creates a rigid oxide shell that can develop voids between the aluminum core and oxide layer as the metal core shrinks. In contrast, in steam environments, new oxide growth occurs at the inner aluminum-oxide interface, with oxygen or water-derived species diffusing inward through the oxide layer. This prevents void formation and subjects the oxide layer to tensile stress at the outer interface. The difference in interface location has significant implications for oxidation completion temperatures: oxidation in steam is complete near 1000°C, while oxidation in dry oxygen requires temperatures up to 1500°C for completion. This represents an actual 500°C difference in completion temperatures between the two environments. The inner interface growth mechanism in steam promotes more rapid oxidation pathways due to geometric constraints and oxide layer porosity development, while the outer interface mechanism in dry oxygen creates diffusion barriers that require higher temperatures for complete oxidation.
